DOC.HEAD: Bush Approves China Satellite Deal
Eds: CORRECTS Eagleburger's first name to Lawrence sted Brent in 5th graf: ``The furor,''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush eased economic sanctions against China on Tuesday as Secretary of State James A. Baker III expressed ``regrets'' he may have misled Americans about high-level U.S. contacts with Beijing. The White House announced that Bush had approved the export of three communications satellites to be launched by China, and had ended a prohibition on the Export-Import Bank providing help to companies doing business in China. The president's actions came as Baker said through a spokeswoman he regretted that in a recent television interview, he may have misled the public about the two trips to China by high-level U.S. officials. Whether the administration was misleading the public prompted close questioning of White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, who mounted a vigorous defense of President Bush's secret contact with the Chinese leadership. The furor erupted after it was learned Monday that national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger had visited Beijing in secret in July, in addition to their previously disclosed trip earlier this month. Bush notified Congress that he was exempting the three communications satellites, which are being built or renovated by the Hughes Aircraft Co., from economic sanctions imposed on China after last June's crackdown in Tiananmen Square. Hughes is selling the satellites to firms in Australia and Hong Kong for launch on a Chinese rocket. ``The sale of these satellites represents approximately $300 million worth of business for U.S. firms,'' said a statement by Fitzwater. The statement said the move was ``consistent with the president's expressed determination, in imposing sanctions last June, to maintain commercial relations with China.'' The July trip came at a time when the administration said high-level visits to Beijing were banned because of the violent suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations in June. Baker, appearing on ABC-TV Dec. 10, called the December trip by Scowcroft and Eagleburger ``the first time we've had high-level U.S. officials go to the People's Republic of China.'' Baker noted he himself had publicly met high Chinese officials in other countries. Asked about the apparent discrepancy, spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Tuesday that Baker ``felt obligated to protect the secrecy of a mission that the President wished to have classified. He regrets that me may have misled some.'' She added: ``He felt that by acknowledging his own direct involvement it was sufficient to make the point that this (December trip) was not the first case of high-level contact.'' Before that statement, she had said Baker did not feel he had lied. On the satellites, the White House statement said, ``Approval of these licences is in keeping with the president's policy not to disrupt normal commercial relations with China.'' Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., called Bush's approval ``a true outrage'' and ``another effort to curry favor with the hardliners in Beijing and an insult to the memory of those who died for democracy in Tiananmen Square.'' Gore sponsored the legislation that forbids the launch of U.S.-manufacturered satellites Chinese rockets unless the president declares it to be in the U.S. national interest, as Bush has done. Before the satellite announcement, Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., said Bush's sending of high-level emissaries to China after the violent Chinese crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators ``makes the president look like a wimp in Beijing and a hypocrite in Washington.'' His comments were in a statement issued while he was traveling in Nepal. Facing criticism from members of Congress that the administration has been too friendly with China in the aftermath of the June crackdown, the White House issued a separate two-page ``justification'' of the satellite action. ``After launch, they will be controlled for civil use,'' the White House statement said. ``It is in the national interest of the United States to approve export licernses for the three satellites currently being prepared for launch in China.'' Two of the satellites are being built by Hughes Aircraft Co. for AUSSAT, an Australian company. The other one is being refurbished by Hughes for AsiaSat, based in Hong Kong. The White House also cited ``national interest'' in waiving restrictions on the Export-Import bank's financing of U.S. business activities within China. The bank is a government agency which helps provide a range of assistance to U.S. companies, including low-interest loans, to help them set up overseas operations. The White House said the waiver ``preserves a level playing field for U.S. business. Additional business activity with China will be considered on a case-by-case basis as part of a continuing review process.'' Fitzwater, under close questioning by reporters, declared Bush had not misled Americans, as critics contended. ``It is not misleading to not tell you about everything he's doing,'' Fitzwater said. At the State Department's daily briefing, Tutwiler was asked whether she felt the American public had been misled on U.S. policy toward China. ``I certainly don't think that I've lied,'' she said. ``I know Marlin doesn't think that he's lied. Secretary (of State James A.) Baker doesn't think he's lied and the president doesn't think he's lied.'' Fitzwater said he could not comment on whether there had been other trips to China that still remained secret. But he said, ``There have been trips you don't know about. There will be more.'' Fitzwater said Bush dispatched Scowcroft and Eagleburger in July to make sure that China's hard-line leaders knew the seriousness of U.S. anger over the crushing of the pro-democracy demonstrations. He said it was important to keep the trip secret so the Chinese knew that denunciations of the crackdown were more than public posturing. Denying that the administration had violated its own ban on exchanges with China, Fitzwater said there never was any intention to cut off all high-level contact. He said there was a distinction between high-level ``exchanges'' and high-level ``contacts.''
